Malaysian: saluran najis "najis" means dirty in both languages, saluran kumbahan
Indonesian: selokan, parit (means 'ditch' in Malay), got, saluran air/pembuangan

Malaysian: syampu (from Anglo-Indian / Hindustani chāmpo, the imperative form of (Hindi) चाँप्ना chāmpnā 'to smear, knead the muscles, massage')
berkongsi (In Indonesian, it means "creating trading company" or "plotting something bad")
baju (also in Indonesian but more generally refers to clothes)
Indonesian: kaos, kemeja (from Portuguese camisa, implies collared shirt)

Malaysian: kasut generalized term for any footwear in Indonesian, but usually related to sandals or ancient shoes, sepatu
Indonesian: sepatu (understood but less frequently used in Malaysia, from Portuguese sapato)

Malaysian: tapak (means foundation (building) or footprint in Indonesia)

Indonesian: sodomi, liwat (only used in Islamic text books)
asam, masam (poetic, usually used in connotative expressions: bermuka masam: sour faced (dissatisfied/unhappy expression))

Malaysian: berbicara, bercakap (means 'to chat' in Indonesian), bersembang, berborak

Indonesian: spesialis (in case of specialist doctor), pakar in general, it means expert
olahraga (means "athletics" Malay, from Sanskrit, lit. "to train the body")

Malaysian: pasangan suami-isteri, kelamin colloquial, in Indonesian means "sex" or "gender"
kakitangan (phrase "kaki tangan" means subordinate with negative image in Indonesian)
Indonesian: staf, personil from Dutch personeel, pegawai
bodoh, dungu, tolol, goblok (slang), very demeaning in Malay, geblek (slang), bego (slang)
Minggu (from Portuguese Domingo which means Lord's Day), Ahad (only used in Islamic calendar)

Malaysian: cermin mata gelap (In Indonesia, cermin means "mirror")
Indonesian: kacamata hitam (lit. black glasses), kacamata riben (from 'Ray-Ban' brand of sunglasses )

Malaysian: tinjauan (means process or result of observation in Indonesian), kaji selidik
